column5: New pet peeve: Can articles please stop saying things like ‚ÄúThis is what dining will look like after COVID-19‚Äù when what they MEAN is ‚Äúthis is what dining will look like after the lockdown but still during the pandemic‚Äù? If you‚Äôre talking about measures we have to take to continue to slow the spread of the disease, then they aren‚Äôt POST Covid, are they?? It‚Äôs such a small thing but it bugs the crap out of me because it makes it seem like they‚Äôre saying things will be like that forever

If this is true this could be such a HUGE deal, because up until now we‚Äôve been thinking that only way to really get rid of this was for everyone to get it or to develop a vaccine - if people have immunity without ever having it, that would be SO bomb for the trajectory of the virus

To be fair, and you can downvote me and I won‚Äôt even be mad because I wish this wasn‚Äôt true, Georgia DID report their daily totals out of order which made it look like the cases were going down. Whether it was a mistake or on purpose, I don‚Äôt know, but it‚Äôs not a TOTAL conspiracy theory, there is something going on
!! And this would jive with the article that was posted the other day about people having some immunity to COVID without having had it, potentially from other common colds/viruses

Happy 2 month anniversary from up here in Michigan! Some more good Great Lakes news today: 

"Health officials in Michigan reported [370 new confirmed cases of coronavirus](https://www.mlive.com/public-interest/2020/05/michigan-reports-40-coronavirus-deaths-370-new-confirmed-cases-wednesday.html) yesterday, the **lowest daily total in more than a week**." (and those are wednesday numbers!) Our curve is trending steadily downward.

and...

"Eastern Michigan University, Grand Valley State University, Calvin University and Hillsdale College are among the higher education institutions that have announced plans to **resume in-person, on-campus operations this fall.**" !

I don‚Äôt know how much this helps, but it wasn‚Äôt so much a prophecy as a warning: his comments were that IF the united states can‚Äôt get a solid plan in place, we could be looking at a bad winter. He was urging the government to take more effective action

That freaked me out too, but knowing that Washington Post has been THE poster child for fear mongering I went ahead and read the article, and as far as i can tell the only country they mentioned actually returning to a legit lockdown was Lebanon (and they said it was for four days, so they can do some contact tracing and figure out what was going on) everything else seemed more like they were talking about have to reimplement SOME restrictions (like South Korea going back on their decision to let nightclubs open after that one new outbreak). It‚Äôs not a good news article, but as usual, it doesn‚Äôt seem as bad as the headline makes it sound. At the end of the article, there are even a few good comments from experts, like one of the epidemiology guys in China saying new outbreaks DONT mean a second wave, because now that they have the tools they have to deal with this, they‚Äôre not going to allow those outbreaks to get that far.

Rant, sort of: I HATE WORKING FROM HOME. I‚Äôm not productive, meetings are confusing with zoom, it stresses me out, I miss my coworkers, i miss having a designated place to go each day. I do think it would be a really nice effect of this situation if more people had the ability to work from home, to have that be more of a commonplace option for people with kids, or people with disabilities - people who could really benefit from it. But I‚Äôve been (maybe irrationally) terrified that after the pandemic, companies will just want to continue working remotely, mine included, and i wont get to go back in at all - and I can‚Äôt handle that.

I think something we‚Äôve learned from history is that for better or (often) for worse, humanity has a really short memory. This virus is still brand new, it came on really quickly, and we don‚Äôt know a ton about it right now - but we‚Äôre learning more and more about how to deal with it every day. We‚Äôre very likely to get a vaccine, we‚Äôre very likely to keep getting more and more potential treatments and things to mitigate this. And I know comparing this to the flu is a bit apples to oranges, but the flu does kill thousands of people per year, and that‚Äôs something that we‚Äôve learned to come to terms with as a society - most of us get our flu shots, we keep our kids home from school when they‚Äôre sick, we try to promote better hand washing and other hygiene especially during cold and flu season. If this virus does become a permanent part of our lives (and that‚Äôs a big if) it certainly won‚Äôt always be as severe as it is now, and it‚Äôs something we will adjust to living with.

Because I think everyone agrees with you, that large communal events are part of what makes life worth living. And I think all the people who are militant about the lockdowns aren‚Äôt suggesting that we be locked down forever, they‚Äôre looking at it as a short-term, in the moment necessity, not a change to our way of life from now on - no one wants that.
Oh my god if this is true...!!
The worldwide closed cases percentages went from 84% recovered / 16% deceased to 85% / 15% ! :)
Thank you so much for posting this <3

Good Michigan news today! 

Indicators that show Michigan‚Äôs positive progress in the coronavirus crisis:

**1. Average number of new cases a day has plummeted.**

**2. Deaths are down 45% from a month ago.** 

**3. Hospitalizations are down 64% from a month ago.**

**4. Testing has almost tripled.**

**5. Testing is finding fewer new cases.**

**6. A projection model used by the White House projects a sharp drop in Michigan‚Äôs coronavirus deaths in June and July.**

Some of my favorite quotes: 

>"Even with more testing, the number of cases has declined. In the first seven days of May, Michigan had 3,754 confirmed new COVID-19 cases, compared to 7,818 during the first seven days of April, a 52% drop."  
>  
>  
>  
>‚ÄúWe have not seen a significant jump in the death rate, and hospitalizations have not mirrored the increase in the number of cases we‚Äôre seeing.‚Äù

Basically even with TRIPLE the testing, our new cases are still less than what they were last month, and the case increase isn't leading to a comparable hospitalization increase, meaning a higher percentage of new cases now are mild! Yay Michigan!

[https://www.mlive.com/public-interest/2020/05/7-indicators-that-show-michigans-positive-progress-in-the-coronavirus-crisis.html](https://www.mlive.com/public-interest/2020/05/7-indicators-that-show-michigans-positive-progress-in-the-coronavirus-crisis.html)
I‚Äôm not sure exactly when the worldometers info stops updating, but right now it looks like we had 12805 new cases and 668 deaths today
I hope contactless delivery sticks around, I‚Äôm so socially awkward and I love ordering food without having to talk to anybody üòÇ

I understand this. I‚Äôm definitely not a ‚Äúlet‚Äôs lockdown forever!‚Äù person but it‚Äôs important not to jump the gun, it definitely gives me mixed feelings to hear about state reopenings. 

My state has already extended our stay at home order through the rest of the month, and part of me is super frustrated by that but part of me feels relieved.
Literally alllllll I‚Äôm looking for from society at large is a little nuance! A little moderation! And it‚Äôs so hard to find right now

First, I just want to echo what others have said: This thread has been a total lifesaver for me during this time, and I‚Äôm SO grateful to all of you - without this thread I definitely would be even crazier than I am right now. 

Second, so that this post isn‚Äôt completely useless: Scientists think llama antibodies could be promising in neutralizing COVID! 

https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/06/science/llama-coronavirus-antibodies.html

Plus hasn‚Äôt the ‚Äúmore contagious‚Äù version actually been here for months? Like they‚Äôre not saying it‚Äôs becoming worse right now, they‚Äôre saying that the strain of the virus that America/Canada is dealing with is one that mutated since it originated in Wuhan, right?

Some of the mutating actually might be a good thing - there‚Äôs a lengthier post about it on the good news thread but basically a virus sometimes mutates to be less deadly, so it can spread to more people but not kill its host - this is what happened with the SARS virus, and apparently in some of the research they discovered one example of this mutation in COVID as well!
My friend posted a selfie in an all-black mask with really nice eye makeup on and i was like ‚Äúoh that actually looks kind of badass‚Äù, haha
THANK YOU for posting this!

Yeah, if you‚Äôre frustrated with slower-than-ideal progress in the US, it always helps me to remember that the US is SO large and our population is so spread out that it‚Äôs difficult to lump our progress together as a whole unit. Each individual state is in a totally different stage in the curve at this point. :)
It‚Äôs definitely a relief to have Whitmer as our Governor right now - even with all the protests and pressure to reopen, she‚Äôs not going to open up until it‚Äôs the right decision

I needed a little Michigan positivity today, and I'm glad I found some! 

* On Sunday, MI reported 547 new cases and 29 new deaths - the lowest amount since march. (we know weekend data has to be taken with a grain of salt, but still welcome news) 
* Testing numbers have also shown an increase - on May 1st (the most recent data available), 11385 tests were administered, the highest amount since testing began. 
* Of those tests, only 9.9% came back positive -  our lowest daily percentage so far!

I‚Äôm in no way an expert, but although a second wave seems like a likely possibility, I can not wrap my head around why it would be worse. We‚Äôd be way more prepared for a second wave than we were for the first, we‚Äôll have more treatments, we know a lot more about the disease now than we did initially, everyone is alert now (and therefore being more cautious about hygiene and things like that)

And correct me if I‚Äôm wrong, but wasn‚Äôt the situation in the Spanish Flu pandemic that they didn‚Äôt even start taking social distancing measures and things like that until the second wave had already begun? So it‚Äôs not an apples to apples comparison, timeline-wise (in addition to the war and all the other complications happening during that time)

Something that‚Äôs really fueling my anxiety and frustration right now is the feeling that there‚Äôs no source I can turn to for news without slant. Everything is so biased and politically charged and I don‚Äôt know how seriously to take anything. I‚Äôve just been trying to absorb news from as many different types of sources as possible to make sure I‚Äôm getting every side of it and can have a balanced view, but it‚Äôs tough. Where do you feel like you get your most straightforward information from, do you guys have a trusted source??
SAME, my hair is okay but my eyebrows are WACK

Definitely feel this. I‚Äôm dying for the lockdown to end but at the same time I‚Äôm afraid that by the time it‚Äôs over I won‚Äôt remember how to function normally in
the world anymore

Anyone else feeling guilty about having such a hard time dealing with this situation? In the grand scheme of things, I‚Äôm super lucky - I‚Äôm able to work from home & still get paid and everything, I haven‚Äôt gotten sick or had anyone close to me get seriously sick (knock on wood), nothing super important in my life has been cancelled due to the pandemic. But I‚Äôm having SUCH a tough time, mentally, and the mean part of my brain keeps reminding me ‚Äúpeople are literally dying, don‚Äôt be such a selfish baby.‚Äù Relatable?

This is super interesting - I‚Äôm the furthest from an expert, but i had been wondering about the idea of trying to gain herd immunity by allowing low risk people to contract the virus while sheltering high risk groups and therefore hopefully preventing the majority of deaths

This isn't really news, but an observation: every day I check the trending news on twitter, and even there, where hysteria typically abounds, I've noticed a SIGNIFICANT decrease in hysterical doom articles and updates. I think if even twitter can't drum up as much panic as before, that's a good sign about the progress being made.

Amazing to read this

Recovery numbers are looking great, but for anyone anxious that they aren't even higher, remember that there are a lot of requirements to officially being declared "recovered". 

*"Both medical and testing criteria must be met before a person is* [*officially declared recovered*](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/hcp/disposition-in-home-patients.html)*.*

*Medically, a person must be fever-free without fever-reducing medications for three consecutive days. They must show an improvement in their other symptoms, including reduced coughing and shortness of breath. And it must be at least seven full days* [*since the symptoms began*](https://health.usnews.com/conditions/articles/coronavirus-recovery-what-to-know)*.* 

*In addition to those requirements, the CDC guidelines say that a person must test negative for the coronavirus twice, with the* [*tests taken at least 24 hours apart*](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/if-you-are-sick/care-for-someone.html)*.* 

*Only then, if both the symptom and testing conditions are met, is a person officially considered recovered by the CDC.*

*This second testing requirement is likely why there were so few official recovered cases in the U.S. until late March. Initially, there was a* [*massive shortage of testing in the U.S.*](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/18/health/coronavirus-test-shortages-face-masks-swabs.html) *So while many people were certainly recovering over the last few weeks, this could not be officially confirmed. As the country enters the height of the pandemic in the coming weeks, focus is still on* [*testing those who are infected*](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-nCoV/hcp/clinical-criteria.html)*, not those who have likely recovered."* 

[https://theconversation.com/what-does-recovered-from-coronavirus-mean-4-questions-answered-about-how-some-survive-and-what-happens-next-134883](https://theconversation.com/what-does-recovered-from-coronavirus-mean-4-questions-answered-about-how-some-survive-and-what-happens-next-134883)
